Seminars

A complete list of all CABA related Seminars.

  • 2015

    May 7th

    New Approaches for Responding to Climate Change in the San Francisco Bay-Delta

  • 2015

    Mar 3rd

    Sturgeon in the Sacramento - San Joaquin Watershed. New insights to support conservation and management.

  • 2014

    Dec 9th

    Meeting Nature Halfway on a Floodway

    Current Understanding and Future Interactions with a Changing Landscape

  • 2014

    May 12th

    Emerging Techniques to Quantify the Effects of Environmental Change in Bay-Delta Organisms

    Current Understanding and Future Interactions with a Changing Landscape

  • 2014

    Feb 18th

    Lower Food Web Dynamics in California's Bay-Delta EcoSystem:

    Current Understanding and Future Interactions with a Changing Landscape

  • 2013

    Jun 10th

    Tidal Marshes and Native Fishes in the Delta: Will Restoration Make a Difference?

    Sponsors of this seminar are: The Delta Science Program, The U.C. Davis Center for Aquatic Biology and Aquaculture (CABA) and the California Nevada Chapter of the American Fisheries Society

  • 2013

    Jun 7th

    Development Priorities for Vietnamese Fisheries and Aquaculture: The Contribution of Nha Trang University

  • 2013

    Jan 18th

    What is a Natural Hydrograph in Regulated Rivers? The Science of Natural Flows to the Delta

  • 2012

    May 23rd

    Beyond Suisun - What are we Missing? Estuary Ecology of Juvenile Salmonids

  • 2012

    Mar 12th

    Effect of Introduced Trout on Alpine Lake Benthic Invertebrate Communities

  • 2011

    May 23rd

    From fish jumping to invasive species and back again - 11 years of post U.C. Davis work

    Dr. Chris Myrick from Colorado State University will present a seminar entitled: From fish jumping to invasive species and back again - 11 years of post U.C. Davis work.

  • 2011

    May 23rd

    Suisun Marsh in the 21st Century: A Landscape of Change & Opportunity

    A symposium presented by the Center for Aquatic Biology and Aquaculture at UC Davis (CABA) and sponsored by the Delta Stewardship Council and the Center for Watershed Sciences
